text: import numpy as np np.random.seed(0) ########################################### # VARIABLES FOR LAYERS num_hidden_layers = 128 hidden_layer_neurons = 128 input_neurons = 128 output_neurons = 128  ########################################### # Objects class Layer:     # initialize the layer     def __init__(self, n_inputs, n_neurons):         self.weights = 0.10 * np.random.randn(n_inputs, n_neurons)         self.biases = np.zeros((1, n_neurons))     # Forward feed the layer     def forward(self, inputs, activation_func):         out = np.dot(inputs, self.weights) + self.biases         if activation_func == "ReLU":             self.output = np.maximum(0, out)         else:             self.output = out  ########################################### # Inputs to the network X = [list(np.random.randn(input_neurons))]  ########################################### # init input layer layerI = Layer(n_inputs=len(X[0]), n_neurons=hidden_layer_neurons) # init hidden layers layersH = [] i = num_hidden_layers while i > 0:     layersH.append(Layer(n_inputs=hidden_layer_neurons, n_neurons=hidden_layer_neurons))     i = i - 1 # init output layer layerO = Layer(n_inputs=hidden_layer_neurons, n_neurons=output_neurons)  ########################################### # forward input layer layerI.forward(X, activation_func="ReLU") # forward hidden layers prevLayerOut = layerI.output # output of previous layer for layer in layersH:     layer.forward(prevLayerOut, activation_func="ReLU") # current layer forward     prevLayerOut = layer.output # update prev layer output # forward output layer layerO.forward(prevLayerOut, activation_func="ReLU")  ########################################### # print the output layer print(layerO.output)

text: For anyone who is following along and doesn't want to write it out: def create_data(points,classes):     X=np.zeros((points*classes,2))     y= np.zeros(points*classes,dtype = 'uint8')     for class_number in range(classes):         ix = range(points*class_number, points*(class_number +1))         r= np.linspace(0,1, points)         t=np.linspace(class_number*4,(class_number+1)*4, points) + np.random.randn(points)*.2         X[ix] = np.c_[r*np.sin(t*2.5), r*np.cos(t*2.5)]         y[ix] = class_number     return X,y

author: @morthim
text: why would we have a null section of the function? the activation functions are ___/ but when you get beyond some arbitrary domain the function stops being used. so why have the flat part of the line? why have part of the activation function be not activated? why not just have "from domain point x1 to domain point x2; y1 =initial height,y2 = domain finishing height"   another related thing which confuses me is that your criticism of the best fit line for your sin wave is why overfitting can occur. why isn't there a gradient of fits? the 2 point fit is that "bad" one. if you add 2 more points, you can have the x min, x max, and y min, and y max; that would create an approximation which is sometimes called a triangle curve or triangle wave form. yes you can approximate the waveform better through a RELU, but you can get a very similar derivative function with far fewer fitting points, by focusing on topological traits like minimums and maximums. yes you would need to do something different a bit if you were trying to approximate area under the curve. but tessellation itself could be done by factoring out functions. let's say you want to fit lines to the function, and you have data which falls outside of the lines, but by eyeball you know it could still be under the real function. you find the place where teh r^2 value is most off, then offset the best fit function. this gives a metadomain. factor out the original function and you get a -x^2 function. create another triangle approximation, see if it is inside, and do the offset again if not. repeat until determined to satisfaction. over fitting is still possible, but by spreading fit across layers it becomes harder to accidentally do. also if you don't need intermediate spaces, you reduce the additional cost of fit from some sort of a math thing, to n FLOPs- with n being the number of dimensions of the dataset.
